scenes.contextText: Glenmark Pharmaceuticals’ Q2 FY26 results tell a story far deeper than profit and loss. At first glance, the quarter reports a loss, but this was not caused by weak sales or slowing demand.

The impact came from one-time exceptional charges of over ₹3,200 crore, set aside to resolve long-running U.S. antitrust lawsuits, bringing legal closure while the company continues to deny any admission of wrongdoing.
Operational strength remained intact, with consolidated revenue for the quarter crossing ₹60,000 crore, reflecting Glenmark’s scale across global markets.
Then came the turning point — Glenmark’s innovation arm signed a landmark $700 million global licensing deal with AbbVie, validating its research pipeline and reshaping future cash-flow visibility.

Alongside this, the company restructured operations, transferred its consumer business, streamlined costs, and still declared an interim dividend of ₹2.50 per share. This quarter wasn’t about short-term profits; it was about clearing uncertainty, strengthening the core, and positioning for the next phase of growth.
